docs.snippet: A Q&A with Charles Ferguson, director of "Inside Job," a documentary on the financial crisis....
docs.lead_paragraph: "Inside Job," a documentary on the financial crisis by director Charles Ferguson, screens Friday and Monday at the New York Film Festival and opens in theaters on Oct. 8. Narrated by Matt Damon, the movie features interviews with the likes of Nouriel Roubini; Christine Lagarde, the French finance minister; and Representative Barney Frank.
docs.abstract: A Q&A with Charles Ferguson, director of "Inside Job," a documentary on the financial crisis.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''And Justice for All'' (editorial, May 26): Perhaps an appropriate punishment for Kenneth L. Lay and Jeffrey K. Skilling, the convicted former Enron chief executives, would be mandatory assistance for those companies that must now struggle to meet the onerous requirements of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002.

headline.main: Cleaning Up After the Enron Verdicts

docs.snippet: The Enron founder has become increasingly agitated, lashing out at what he portrayed as a cabal of former Enron executives, investors and journalists....
docs.lead_paragraph: After waiting 13 weeks to respond to his accusers, Kenneth L. Lay lost his legendary cool on the witness stand Wednesday. Just minutes into his cross-examination by a prosecutor, John Hueston, Mr. Lay, Enron's founder and former chief executive, testily accused Mr. Hueston of personally preventing him from repaying a company credit line Mr. Lay had used to shore up his personal finances.

headline.main: Lay Loses His Cool On Stand

byline.original: By ALEXEI BARRIONUEVO and SIMON ROMERO

docs.abstract: Jesse Lava letter notes that Feb 26 article said former Enron Corp chmn Kenneth L Lay is facing financial ruin because his net worth is less than $650,000

docs.snippet: Kenneth D. Rice rose rapidly in an orgy of fast money and lavish perks at Enron, but will take the stand this week as a humbled government witness....
docs.lead_paragraph: From fast cars to rugged adventure trips to $6.4 million in bonuses, Enron was a dream maker for Kenneth D. Rice. While he was still in his 30's, Mr. Rice, a former Nebraska farm boy and high school jock, pocketed millions of dollars working for the Houston-based energy company. He lived life in the fast lane -- literally -- racing Ferraris and going on daredevil expeditions to southern Mexico and the Australian Outback with his onetime friend and mentor, Jeffrey K. Skilling, Enron's former chief executive.

headline.main: A Dream Comes to Earth In a Houston Courtroom; Head of Enron's Broadband Unit Is Set to Take the Stand

docs.snippet: KENNETH L. LAY and his second in command, Jeffrey K. Skilling, were the public faces of Enron, painting a rosy picture of strong profits and healthy businesses. But as the facts began to tumble out, in the fall of 2001, the company swiftly collaps...
docs.lead_paragraph: KENNETH L. LAY and his second in command, Jeffrey K. Skilling, were the public faces of Enron, painting a rosy picture of strong profits and healthy businesses. But as the facts began to tumble out, in the fall of 2001, the company swiftly collapsed, taking with it the fortunes and retirement savings of thousands of employees. Tomorrow is the first day of the trial of Mr. Lay, who as founder and chairman is accused of seven counts of fraud and conspiracy, and Mr. Skilling, his chief executive, who faces dozens of counts, including fraud, conspiracy and insider trading.
docs.abstract: Article on 10 major figures in Enron trial and where they are now; says investor relations director Mark Koenig remained at company until spring 2002, pleaded guilty to aiding and abetting securities fraud in 2004 and could face up to 10 years in prison; holds Koenig has paid almost $1.5 million in fines and forfeitures to settle civil charges, changed his plea deal and has agreed to cooperate in case against former bosses (S)

headline.main: 10 Enron Players: Where They Landed After the Fall
